titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Barbara Wertheim Tuchman Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 09:24

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, articles, speeches, printed material, research materials, photographs, and drafts of books relating to Barbara Tuchman's literary career, including such works as Bible and Sword , The Zimmermann Telegram , The Guns of August , and The Proud Tower .

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: No previously unpublished work of Barbara Tuchman's -- such as articles, speeches, parts of unfinished books, letters or juvenilia -- may be published either as a collection of fugitive pieces in a volume under her name or singly in a periodical under her name. Quotations or excerpts from her papers may be used for research purposes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Barbara Wertheim Tuchman Papers (MS 574). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Barbara Tuchman 1965, 1979, and 1982, and Book of the Month Club, 1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Personal. II. Writings.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Barbara Wertheim Tuchman was born in 1912, and received her B.A. degree from Radcliffe College in 1933. She served as a research assistant for the Institute for Pacific Relations, 1934-1935; was an editorial assistant at The Nation , 1936-1937; a staff writer for War in Spain , London, 1937-1938; American correspondent for New Statesman and Nation , London, 1939; and was with the Far East news desk, OWI, 1944-1945. Tuchman was best known as the author of many books and articles. She was the recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in 1963 and 1972. Tuchman died in 1989.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, articles, speeches, printed material, research materials, photographs, and drafts of books relating to Barbara Tuchman's literary career, including such works as Bible and Sword , The Zimmermann Telegram , The Guns of August , and The Proud Tower .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal materials contain correspondence, documents, printed material, reprints, lists, phonograph records, newspaper clippings and handwritten drafts, Included in this series are biographical information, letters of rejection from publishers, information about Mrs. Tuchman's service on various committees, honorary degrees, early writings from childhood and college, a scrapbook of clippings of her early journalistic work, a phonograph record of an interview with Mrs. Tuchman and miscellaneous lists and reprints.
The series is arranged by type of material; and within each type is in chronological order.

did.physdesc: 9.5 linear feet (24 Boxes, 4 Folios, 6 Card file boxes)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material contained in this series includes books, articles, a broadcast, letters to the editor, a poem, reviews, and speeches.

The books include Bible & Sword , The Zimmermann Telegram , The Guns of August , and The Proud Tower . They are arranged alphabetically by title. Included within each unit are the correspondence, research materials, various drafts, and illustrations, pertinent to the various works.

The articles and speeches are basically arranged chronologically, as are the letters to the editor. These writings cover such topics as historical events, current affairs and historiography. A fairly substantial section of the writings pertains to Israel.

The reviews deal with Thomas Woodrow Wilson by William C. Bullitt and Sigmund Freud, Ludendorff by D.J. Goodspeed, Justice in Jerusalem by Gideon Hausner, The Fall of Paris by Alistair Horne, Dare Call It Treason by Richard M. Watt, and Hitler's Spies and Saboteurs by Charles Wighton and Gunter Peis. The reviews are arranged alphabetically by the name of the author of the book.

did.physdesc: 1.5 linear feet (1 Paige box, 1 archive box)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Select correspondence, together with correspondence and printed matter or organizations to which BT belongs or contributes, correspondence and clippings concerning awards, and some fan mail. There is little personal correspondence, and for the most part BT has not kept copies of her replies. Within each folder, letters are not arranged either alphabetically or chronologically; nor is all the correspondence with a person likely to be grouped together. Some correspondents have not been identified, and some items appear to be misfiled. Note also the topical folders "History," "Ideas," "Israel," and "Tuchman-Biographical;" these contain some notes and drafts as well as correspondence.
